questions.text: A 63-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 7-week history of diarrhea and intermittent abdominal pain. She has had 4–5 watery bowel movements per day. She has not had any nausea or bloating and has not changed her diet. Since the onset of her symptoms, she has had a 1.8-kg (4-lb) weight loss. Medical history is remarkable for chronic tension-type headaches, gastroesophageal reflux disease, and rheumatoid arthritis. She has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for the past 25 years. Current medications include ibuprofen, omeprazole, and hydroxychloroquine. She is 171 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 63 kg (139 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 91/min, and blood pressure is 116/69 mm Hg. The abdomen is nondistended, soft, nontender, and no masses are felt on palpation. Bowel sounds are normal. Rectal examination shows no abnormalities. Hemoglobin concentration is 11.2 g/dL and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 26 mm/h. Test of the stool for occult blood is negative. Stool cultures are negative. Ileocolonoscopy shows normal terminal ileal mucosa and normal colonic mucosa on macroscopic examination. Microscopic examination of biopsy specimens from the colon shows intraepithelial lymphocytic infiltrates. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with ulcerative colitis (UC) can also present with abdominal pain, diarrhea, weight loss, anemia, and an increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate. However, colonoscopy findings for these patients typically include friable mucosa and/or crypt abscesses. In addition, UC typically manifests with bloody rather than nonbloody diarrhea. Furthermore, individuals who smoke have a decreased risk of UC compared to those who do not smoke.
Image Description:

Endoscopic view of the sigmoid colon

The mucosa is erythematous and edematous. There is a loss of superficial vascular markings. Several linear, semi-confluent ulcerations (green overlay) are visible.

These findings are characteristic of acute ulcerative colitis.

B) CORRECT:

Chronic nonbloody diarrhea and abdominal pain in conjunction with normal appearing colonic mucosa on colonoscopy are hallmarks of microscopic colitis (MC). Although the exact etiology remains unknown, MC is associated with a number of risk factors, such as age > 50 years, female sex, certain medications, smoking, and a history of autoimmune conditions (e.g., celiac disease, rheumatoid arthritis, type 1 diabetes mellitus). The diagnosis is typically confirmed on biopsy, which shows intraepithelial lymphocytic infiltrates in lymphocytic MC (as seen in this patient) or thick, subepithelial collagen bands in collagenous MC. About 50% of patients with MC also present with mild anemia and increased inflammatory markers. Treatment usually consists of management of risk factors (e.g., smoking cessation, discontinuation of any triggering medications) and symptomatic therapy (e.g., loperamide for diarrhea), followed by therapy escalation with corticosteroids.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a colon tissue sample (H&E stain; 200× magnification)

Increased amounts of intraepithelial lymphocytes (examples indicated by green overlay) are dispersed between the enterocytes (example indicated by blue overlay), with > 20 lymphocytes per 100 enterocytes visible. There are no neutrophils nor is there architectural distortion, which would indicate infectious colitis or inflammatory bowel disease, respectively.

Increased intraepithelial lymphocytes in the absence of neutrophils and architectural distortion is characteristic of lymphocytic colitis, a type of microscopic colitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with celiac disease (CD) can also present with abdominal pain, diarrhea, weight loss, anemia, increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and intraepithelial lymphocytosis on biopsy of the affected segment of the gastrointestinal tract. However, CD affects the distal duodenum and jejunum, not the colon, and biopsy specimens of the affected regions typically also show atrophic villi and crypt hyperplasia in addition to intraepithelial lymphocytic infiltrates. Furthermore, the onset of CD usually occurs before 30–40 years of age.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen of duodenal tissue (H&E stain; low magnification)

Intraepithelial lymphocytosis (examples indicated by arrowheads), villous atrophy (dashed outline showing the approximate height of a normal villus), and crypt hyperplasia (example indicated by green overlay) are visible.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) can also present with abdominal discomfort and diarrhea. However, IBS is a clinical diagnosis and microscopic changes in the colonic mucosa are uncommon. Furthermore, anemia, weight loss, and increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate are inconsistent with IBS.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with Crohn disease can also present with abdominal pain, diarrhea, weight loss, anemia, and an increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and smoking is a risk factor for this condition. However, ileocolonoscopy in these patients typically shows discontinuous areas of transmural inflammation and mucosa with a cobblestone pattern. This patient's ileocolonoscopy shows no abnormalities on macroscopic examination, which suggests another disorder.
Image Description:

Endoscopic view of the terminal ileum

Erythema and small aphthous ulcerations are visible on the mucosa. The edematous surface resembles a cobblestone appearance.

These findings are characteristic of Crohn disease.
questions.hint: This patient's use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and proton pump inhibitors and her history of smoking are risk factors for this condition.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man with a long-standing history of celiac disease reports a 3-month history of watery diarrhea. He says that he has adhered to his gluten-free diet. He has no abdominal pain, hematochezia, or weight loss, and he has not taken any new medications.
His serum tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibody level and total IgA level are normal. A 24-hour stool fat collection is within normal limits.
Which one of the following diagnoses is the most likely cause of this patient’s diarrhea?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Refractory sprue is unlikely in an individual who has an undetectable tTG-IgA level and was previously responding to a gluten-free diet.

B) INCORRECT:

Small-bowel lymphoma is possible in chronic celiac disease, but patients typically have other symptoms, such as abdominal pain, weight loss, or both.

C) INCORRECT:

Pancreatic insufficiency is an unlikely cause of chronic diarrhea in a patient with no preexisting pancreatic disease. Patients with pancreatic insufficiency often develop steatorrhea.

D) CORRECT:

In a patient with celiac disease who adheres strictly to a gluten-free diet and has been asymptomatic, the most likely cause of new-onset diarrhea is the development of microscopic colitis. The two types of microscopic colitis are lymphocytic and collagenous colitis, both of which manifest with watery diarrhea. The colonic mucosa can appear normal at colonoscopy; biopsy is required to identify the abnormality. There is a known association between microscopic colitis and celiac disease.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of a 3-month history of diarrhea in a person with celiac disease who is maintaining a gluten-free diet is microscopic colitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Gluten ingestion does cause recurrent or refractory diarrhea in people with celiac disease, but this patient is maintaining a gluten-free diet. When exposed to gluten, patients with celiac disease typically develop detectable serum markers (endomysial antibody or tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibody [tTG-IgA]), even if those levels were previously low or undetectable. This patient's tTG-IgA level remains normal.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman reports a 5-week history of loose, watery stools, requiring up to 10 bowel movements per day. She received intravenous volume repletion in an emergency department one week ago.
The patient reports occasional crampy abdominal pain but no gastrointestinal bleeding or melena. She has lost 3 kg of weight in the past 3 months. Last year, she had a similar unexplained episode that lasted approximately 4 months and resolved spontaneously.
Her current medications include aspirin, metoprolol, omeprazole, and levothyroxine. She reports no history of alcohol use. A colonoscopy 6 years ago was unremarkable.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic pancreatitis with pancreatic insufficiency and steatorrhea would be unlikely to remit spontaneously.

B) INCORRECT:

Lactose intolerance and small intestinal bacterial overgrowth rarely cause diarrhea sufficient to induce volume depletion.

C) CORRECT:

Microscopic colitis is a common cause of chronic watery diarrhea, especially in older people, and appears to be more frequent in women than in men. The etiology is unknown but may result from autoimmunity or an immune-mediated or an inflammatory response to intraluminal antigens. The disease appears to be associated with the use of aspirin, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, proton pump inhibitors, histamine-2-receptor antagonists, selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitors, ticlopidine, acarbose, and statins.

Diagnosis of microscopic colitis is made by clinical history and characteristic histopathologic findings on biopsies, especially from the right colon. The clinical course is more often intermittent than continuous. First-line therapy includes cessation of any offending agents and a trial of bismuth, 5-aminosalicylic medications, or budesonide.

Key learning point: The medications associated with induction of microscopic colitis include nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, proton pump inhibitors, histamine-2-receptor antagonists, selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitors, ticlopidine, acarbose, and statins.

D) INCORRECT:

Ulcerative colitis is unlikely in the absence of gastrointestinal bleeding.

E) INCORRECT:

Lactose intolerance and small intestinal bacterial overgrowth rarely cause diarrhea sufficient to induce volume depletion.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman is evaluated for symptoms of watery diarrhea, stool incontinence, and weight loss (2.5 kg) that began about 6 months ago without any obvious precipitating event. She denies abdominal pain or blood in her stool, and she has not traveled. She had a screening colonoscopy 8 months ago that was normal. Her only medication is daily ibuprofen, which she has taken for one year for osteoarthritis.
Her physical examination is unremarkable. Her blood counts and comprehensive metabolic panel are normal. Colonoscopy is performed and is again normal. Colon biopsies reveal lymphocytic infiltrates.
In addition to discontinuing nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medications, which one of the following initial treatments is most appropriate for this patient's diarrhea?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics (such as rifaximin and metronidazole) and anthelmintics (such as albendazole) are not warranted in a patient with features of microscopic colitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics (such as rifaximin and metronidazole) and anthelmintics (such as albendazole) are not warranted in a patient with features of microscopic colitis.

C) CORRECT:

This patient likely has microscopic colitis. The main presenting symptom of this condition is chronic watery, nonbloody diarrhea. In patients with microscopic colitis, the colon appears normal endoscopically and radiographically; however, colonic biopsies show unique inflammatory changes. No definite etiology is known, but the condition is associated with certain medications, particularly nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs and selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitors. In some cases, symptoms improve with dietary restriction and avoidance of the potentially aggravating medications, but many individuals require medical therapy. Before appropriate treatment is chosen, other causes of nonbloody diarrhea should be excluded, and a colonoscopy with colon biopsies should be completed.

The first-line treatment for moderate-to-severe symptomatic microscopic colitis is budesonide 9 mg daily. For mild symptoms, bismuth subsalicylate or loperamide can be used initially. In this case, the severity of symptoms (incontinence and weight loss) warrants budesonide as initial therapy.

Key learning point: The development of chronic watery, nonbloody diarrhea in a patient who is routinely using nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medicines should prompt evaluation and treatment for microscopic colitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics (such as rifaximin and metronidazole) and anthelmintics (such as albendazole) are not warranted in a patient with features of microscopic colitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Prednisone is used to treat inflammatory bowel disease, but inflammatory bowel disease is more typically associated with bloody diarrhea and an abnormal colonoscopy. Although prednisone may treat the symptoms of microscopic colitis, it is systemically absorbed and therefore associated with the systemic side effects of chronic glucocorticoid therapy. Budesonide, on the other hand, acts locally with minimal systemic side effects and is therefore a better option in this case.
